Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Komast pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of rosette in added red and added white outline; exterior: narrow band at rim; below, black-figure decoration consisting of komast to right (raised muscular arm remaining, seemingly holding a slanting object, though the hand is lost).
Curator's comments: Lemos illustrates this sherd upside down, however, it is a rim sherd. Lemos places this sherd in Group F of the Black Figure Komast Chalices. The chalices in this group represent the end of the style. The komasts are depicted so simply they appear almost like stick figures, there is little to no filling ornament, incision is careless and the colour is poor and diluted. However, the arm is unusually detailed with the bulging muscles emphasised with the incision marks. Williams argues that the images portrayed on the komast chalices were perhaps representations of komos activities that took place in Chios. The buttock pads exaggerated the dancers’ bottoms. The sakkos worn by many of these komasts as well as the earrings suggest the dancers, who were male, were practicing a form of transvestism. If so, these Chians dancers were precursors of the magodoi or performers who wore women’s clothing, made lewd gestures and performed as female and drunk characters. The gestures of the dancers on the chalices are limited and consist of holding pomegranates, tambourines (or wreaths) and snapping fingers. Such dances may also have been connected to religious festivals and performed after religious feasts. Williams, 1983, 162-3
